results.title: Evolution through time
results.creator_credit: Robert Lattanzio and Corporation for Community Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 11 of Series “Earth revealed”.
Geologists, in their examination of the Earth’s structure, have made important discoveries which have cast new light on the process of evolution. Collecting fossil evidence of microscopic organisms and larger, more complex organisms such as moulds, Scientists can determine when life began on the planet. The extinction of such species such as dinosaurs, or the changes in a species such as that of a horse, can be examined using geological evidence found in rock formations.

results.title: Geologic time
results.creator_credit: Robert Lattanzio and Corporation for Community Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 10 of Series “Earth revealed”.
Geological time runs on a different time scale to that which can be measured in years or by clocks. In the 1700’s, James Harvey, a Scot, was the pioneer of measuring geological time and sparked a controversy as his observations about uplift and erosion which occured in various layers of rock, was in direct conflict with the supporters of The Bible and Genesis belief in Creation. Faunal succession, the analysis of different species of fossils preserved in layers of sediments, and the use of radiocarbon dating are used to give a more exact picture of the age of the planet.

results.title: Earthquakes
results.creator_credit: Robert Lattanzio and Corporation for Community Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 9 of Series “Earth revealed”.
Earthquakes are evidence of the heat energy that powers movement in the Tectonic Plates. Although they cause destruction, the upheaval of the landscape to produce different elevations is ultimately benficial to the Earth. Without this variance, the power of erosion would turn the surface of the Earth into a vast desert plain. Geologists are fascinated by the measurement of earth movements and this episode examines some of these including the Richter Scale and the use of seismic waves to locate and identify the location and source of earthquakes.

results.title: Earth's structures
results.creator_credit: Robert Lattanzio and Corporation for Community Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series “Earth revealed”.
Geographical features like mountains are evidence of the tremendous forces that occur within the Earth such as the movement of the Tectonic Plates. The faults and folds of rocks, caused by this movement often results in vertical motion which causes rises and layering in the landscape. This episode looks at the crustal stresses, the principle of Original Horizontality, the formation of resources such as petrol and the measurement of de-formation of land structures.

results.title: Plate dynamics
results.creator_credit: Robert Lattanzio and Corporation for Community Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “Earth revealed”.
Although a relatively new accepted field in Geology, the theory of Plate Tectonics, has enabled geologists to understand the ways in which the Earth’s plates move and interact. Three types of plate movements have been analysed and involve convergence of two plates, the divergence of plates and in the case of geological phenomena like the San Andreas Fault, Transformation Faults whereby the continental plates are continually slipping past each other.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Robert Lattanzio and Corporation for Community Television

results.title: Talk (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Doug Wilcox, Roger Owen and BBC-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Early years at school”
Stresses the importance of talking as a medium of communication for children aged three to nine years regardless of whether or not it takes the standard middle-class form.
Suitable for teacher/tertiary levels.

results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Early years at school”.
Deals analytically with areas of importance and concern to teachers of children aged three to nine. Examines the question of why most children learn to read but do not always read for pleasure or purpose.

results.title: PR-25 16mm Sound Cinecamera
results.brief_description: The RCA Victor Sound 16mm Camera was introduced in 1934, five years after Hollywood’s conversion to sound pictures. It was the world’s first 16mm sound on film camera and an early technical leap in the sound-on-film process for the amateur market.

constellations_other.name: Amateur hour
constellations_other.description: Early sound equipment allowed filmmakers and amateurs alike the ability to experiment often with affordable 16mm film.

results.description:
RCA Victor Company Inc., Camden, New York, USA. Serial no. 24171.

Written by Chelsey O’Brien, curator, ACMI:

The RCA Victor Sound 16mm Camera was introduced in 1934, five years after Hollywood’s conversion to sound pictures. The RCA Sound camera was the world’s first 16mm sound on film camera and was marketed towards amateur film makers.

The RCA sound camera was capable of shooting one hundred feet of black and white film while recording synchronized sound of the same role, ideal for direct sound recording while filming. The soundtrack was recorded on the edge of the film by a beam of light from a small battery-operated lamp, reflected from a small mirror attached to a diaphragm vibrated by speech from the camera operator. The camera operator could speak commentary which was recorded as a variable area soundtrack along the edge of the film. This placement however meant that the microphone also recorded sound from the camera’s spring-loaded motor. Once film was developed it could be played back on RCA’s sound projector, released a few years earlier to project studio-made sound films.

The RCA sound camera is an important addition to the ACMI Collection as it articulates a vital and historically early technical leap in the amateur film market as well as the sound on film process. Furthermore, it is representative of what would have been used in Australia in late 19th Century.

Technical details: Cinecamera for 16mm film, 100 foot reels. Wollensak Velostigmat lens f/3.5-16, in three-lens turret, screw mount. Clockwork motor drive, 16-24 feet per second. Single sprocket and claw mechanism. Sound recording head, 4 volt 0.75 amp lamp lit from three dry cells. Level adjusting screw. Critical focusing device (under red rubber cap). Direct vision optical finder with frames for three lenses. Paralax compensated rear lens. Footage indicator working on feed spool. Light from lamp falls on recording slit via mirror fitted on ‘microphone’ diaphragm.

From Science Museum UK catalogue: The RCA sound camera was produced for direct sound recording while filming. The sound track was recorded on the edge of the film by a beam of light from a small battery operated lamp, reflected from a small mirror attached to a diaphragm vibrated by speech from the camera operator. The camera operator could speak commentary which was recorded as a variable area sound track along the edge of the film.

From ebay seller: RCA 16mm sound motion picture camera with windier on side, handle on top and base has a power lead connector. The RCA 16mm Sound Camera was the first of its kind made in the USA. There were only a few made, perhaps less then 40. WWII stopped the development of 16mm sound camera and RCA discontinued the project. The camera operates with a spring wound motor and flashlight batteries to power the sound. It accepts a 16mm 100ft Daylight load of film, Spring Wound Motor
description_for_label:
RCA Victor Company Inc., Camden, New York, USA. Serial no. 24171.

Written by Chelsey O’Brien, curator, ACMI:

The RCA Victor Sound 16mm Camera was introduced in 1934, five years after Hollywood’s conversion to sound pictures. The RCA Sound camera was the world’s first 16mm sound on film camera and was marketed towards amateur film makers.

The RCA sound camera was capable of shooting one hundred feet of black and white film while recording synchronized sound of the same role, ideal for direct sound recording while filming. The soundtrack was recorded on the edge of the film by a beam of light from a small battery-operated lamp, reflected from a small mirror attached to a diaphragm vibrated by speech from the camera operator. The camera operator could speak commentary which was recorded as a variable area soundtrack along the edge of the film. This placement however meant that the microphone also recorded sound from the camera’s spring-loaded motor. Once film was developed it could be played back on RCA’s sound projector, released a few years earlier to project studio-made sound films.

The RCA sound camera is an important addition to the ACMI Collection as it articulates a vital and historically early technical leap in the amateur film market as well as the sound on film process. Furthermore, it is representative of what would have been used in Australia in late 19th Century.

Technical details: Cinecamera for 16mm film, 100 foot reels. Wollensak Velostigmat lens f/3.5-16, in three-lens turret, screw mount. Clockwork motor drive, 16-24 feet per second. Single sprocket and claw mechanism. Sound recording head, 4 volt 0.75 amp lamp lit from three dry cells. Level adjusting screw. Critical focusing device (under red rubber cap). Direct vision optical finder with frames for three lenses. Paralax compensated rear lens. Footage indicator working on feed spool. Light from lamp falls on recording slit via mirror fitted on ‘microphone’ diaphragm.

From Science Museum UK catalogue: The RCA sound camera was produced for direct sound recording while filming. The sound track was recorded on the edge of the film by a beam of light from a small battery operated lamp, reflected from a small mirror attached to a diaphragm vibrated by speech from the camera operator. The camera operator could speak commentary which was recorded as a variable area sound track along the edge of the film.

From ebay seller: RCA 16mm sound motion picture camera with windier on side, handle on top and base has a power lead connector. The RCA 16mm Sound Camera was the first of its kind made in the USA. There were only a few made, perhaps less then 40. WWII stopped the development of 16mm sound camera and RCA discontinued the project. The camera operates with a spring wound motor and flashlight batteries to power the sound. It accepts a 16mm 100ft Daylight load of film, Spring Wound Motor
